slides.templateDescription: Swipe through a gallery of images

images.caption: # It's clear that rules need to be followed and safeguards implemented.
# Safeguards should  include creating a culture of the "HIPAA mindset," an unrelenting focus on securing and respecting the privacy of each patient.
# What follows is a list of practices to help you begin to develop a HIPAA mindset.
# But, every organization is different, and you need  good risk and security analyses to identify your own threats and vulnerability.

slides.templateDescription: Display a list of bullet points

data.prompt: Select an item to see more

list.content:
Conduct a **comprehensive risk analysis** - if you don't know how to do it, hire somebody who does.

Every **safeguard** you implement depends on the specific findings of the risk analysis.

If the analysis is incomplete or inaccurate, safeguards will be inadequate, and you will be at **increased risk**!
list.title: Conduct

list.content:
Implement **layered network security** and **safeguards**. 

If you don’t know how to do it, hire someone who does - don’t just ignore it.
list.title: Implement

list.content: Remember, **ALL** of the safeguards are important.
list.title: Remember

list.content: Require **strong** passwords for anything that has PHI.
list.title: Require

data.title: **Technical Practices**

slides.templateDescription: Display a long amount of content

data.content:
1. ## Perform comprehensive risk and security analyses
2. ## Identify threats and vulnerabilities
3. ## Select and develop safeguards
4. ## Create policies, procedures, and practices
5. ## Train the staff
6. ## Implement all safeguards
7. ## Manage, monitor, and modify
data.title: **Path to HIPAA Compliance**

slides.templateDescription: Put the items in the correct order

question.content: Put these steps in the correct order

answers.content: Conduct risk and security analyses|Identify appropriate and reasonable safeguards|Develop policies, procedures, and practices|Train your workforce|Implement the safeguards|Monitor and modify security practices as needed

list: Monitor and modify security practices as needed

answer.takeaway:
You must understand the risks, evaluate safeguards, implement solutions, and monitor activity.

A rigorous training program, including regular updates, is an **integral** part of any solution - after all,  it's the people who make security happen.

data.prompt: Put the items in the correct order
data.title: Put these steps in the correct order

slides.templateDescription: Display a list of bullet points

data.prompt: Select an item to see more

list.content:
Appoint Privacy and Security Officers, even if you are a small CE.  <ol>
<li>The law requires it.  
<li>You need a single point of authority.  
<li>You need an enforcer.
list.title: Appoint

list.content:
Train your staff well - but it shouldn’t be seen as a compliance checkbox. It’s the HIPAA version of “a chain is as strong as the weakest link.”

And, don’t make it just an annual thing - reinforcing HIPAA best practices is key to robust privacy and security practices.

Small, frequent delivery of content builds employee confidence, encourages compliance, and decreases employee downtime for training.
list.title: Train

list.content: Implement internal controls, with appropriate checks and balances - no one person should be able to do everything - at least without a method of accountability.
list.title: Implement

list.content: Test on HIPAA - ask staff members "what ifs” with scenarios appropriate for their roles.
list.title: Test

list.content:
Encourage everyone to become a HIPAA best practices advocate and express their concerns and solutions.

If everyone is a potential problem, then everyone’s a source of ideas, too.
list.title: Encourage

data.title: **Administrative Practices**

question.content: Only practices with more than 5,000 patients need Privacy and Security Officers.

answer.takeaway: Under HIPAA , a breach is a breach is a breach - they all need to be reported.

data.title: Only practices with more than 5,000 patients need Privacy and Security Officers.

question.content: In a small practice, it is best if one person can fulfill all of the roles required to implement, maintain, and monitor security safeguards.

answer.takeaway:
Even in a small entity, internal controls - a system of checks and balances - can prevent one person from abusing power.

This isn't a new concept; 2100 years ago, a Roman author asked "_Quis custodiet ipsos custodes_?  - who will watch the watchmen?

data.title: In a small practice, it is best if one person can fulfill all of the roles required to implement, maintain, and monitor security safeguards.

data.label: Practice
content: Be neat - do not let records lay about. Have policies and procedures.
Meet frequently, even informally, to discuss privacy and security.
Reward people who demonstrate good practices.
Build a robust “social firewall” - make your people suspicious of any request for PHI.
Control personal smartphone and device use - well, we can hope.
Banish gossip - make it the office ethic.
Create a collaborative atmosphere, a community of practice, in which all employees are encouraged to participate in building robust security practices.
data.title: **Office Practices**

question.category: Create a collaborative atmosphere, a community of practice, in which all employees are encouraged to participate in building robust security practices.
Create a collaborative atmosphere, a community of practice, in which all employees are encouraged to participate in building robust security practices.
Create a collaborative atmosphere, a community of practice, in which all employees are encouraged to participate in building robust security practices.

answer.takeaway: Culture goes a long way to developing and practicing strong security measures. It's important that individual knowledge, experience and ideas be shared with the larger community.

data.title: Create a collaborative atmosphere, a community of practice, in which all employees are encouraged to participate in building robust security practices.
